æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

In July 2004, Google posted on a giant billboard along Highway 101 in Silicon Valley (shown in the picture below) for recruitment. The content is super-simple, a URL consisting of the first 10-digit prime found in consecutive digits of the natural constant e. The person who could find this prime number could go to the next step in Googleâ€™s hiring process by visiting this website.

The natural constant e is a well known transcendental numberï¼ˆè¶…è¶Šæ•°ï¼‰. The first several digits are: e = 2.718â€¦â€¦..921â€¦ where the 10 digits in bold are the answer to Googleâ€™s question.

Now you are asked to solve a more general problem: find the first K-digit prime in consecutive digits of any given L-digit number.

è¾“å…¥

Each input file contains one test case. Each case first gives in a line two positive integers: L (â‰¤ 1,000) and K (< 10), which are the numbers of digits of the given number and the prime to be found, respectively. Then the L-digit number N is given in the next line.

è¾“å‡º

For each test case, print in a line the first K-digit prime in consecutive digits of N. If such a number does not exist, output 404 instead. Note: the leading zeroes must also be counted as part of the K digits. For example, to find the 4-digit prime in 200236, 0023 is a solution. However the first digit 2 must not be treated as a solution 0002 since the leading zeroes are not in the original number.

In July 2004, Google posted on a giant billboard along Highway 101 in Silicon Valley (shown in the picture below) for recruitment. The content is super-simple, a URL consisting of the first 10-digit prime found in consecutive digits of the natural constant e. The person who could find this prime number could go to the next step in Googleâ€™s hiring process by visiting this website.

The natural constant e is a well known transcendental numberï¼ˆè¶…è¶Šæ•°ï¼‰. The first several digits are: e = 2.718â€¦â€¦..921â€¦ where the 10 digits in bold are the answer to Googleâ€™s question.

Now you are asked to solve a more general problem: find the first K-digit prime in consecutive digits of any given L-digit number.

entry.title: PATç”²çº§-1007-Maximum Subsequence Sum (25 åˆ†)
entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

Given a sequence of $K$ integers { $N_1, N_2, â€¦, N_K$ }. A continuous subsequence is defined to be { $N_i, N_i+1, â€¦, N_j$ } where $1â‰¤iâ‰¤jâ‰¤K$. The Maximum Subsequence is the continuous subsequence which has the largest sum of its elements. For example, given sequence { $-2, 11, -4, 13, -5, -2$ }, its maximum subsequence is { $11, -4, 13$ } with the largest sum being $20$.

Now you are supposed to find the largest sum, together with the first and the last numbers of the maximum subsequence.

è¾“å…¥

Each input file contains one test case. Each case occupies two lines. The first line contains a positive integer $K (â‰¤10000)$. The second line contains $K$ numbers, separated by a space.

è¾“å‡º

For each test case, output in one line the largest sum, together with the first and the last numbers of the maximum subsequence. The numbers must be separated by one space, but there must be no extra space at the end of a line. In case that the maximum subsequence is not unique, output the one with the smallest indices $i$ and $j$ (as shown by the sample case). If all the $K$ numbers are negative, then its maximum sum is defined to be 0, and you are supposed to output the first and the last numbers of the whole sequence.

entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

A family hierarchy is usually presented by a pedigree tree. Your job is to count those family members who have no child.

è¾“å…¥

Each input file contains one test case. Each case starts with a line containing $0<N<100$, the number of nodes in a tree, and $M (<N)$, the number of non-leaf nodes. Then M lines follow, each in the format:

where ID is a two-digit number representing a given non-leaf node, K is the number of its children, followed by a sequence of two-digit IDâ€˜s of its children. For the sake of simplicity, let us fix the root ID to be 01.

The input ends with N being 0. That case must NOT be processed.

è¾“å‡º

For each test case, you are supposed to count those family members who have no child for every seniority levelstarting from the root. The numbers must be printed in a line, separated by a space, and there must be no extra space at the end of each line.

The sample case represents a tree with only 2 nodes, where 01 is the root and 02 is its only child. Hence on the root 01 level, there is 0 leaf node; and on the next level, there is 1 leaf node. Then we should output 0 1 in a line.

entry.title: Codeforces Round #518 (Div. 2) C. Colored Rooks
entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

Ivan is a novice painter. He has $n$ dyes of different colors. He also knows exactly $m$ pairs of colors which harmonize with each other.

Ivan also enjoy playing chess. He has $5000$ rooks. He wants to take $k$ rooks, paint each of them in one of $n$ colors and then place this $k$ rooks on a chessboard of size $10^9Ã—10^9$.

Letâ€™s call the set of rooks on the board connected if from any rook we can get to any other rook in this set moving only through cells with rooks from this set. Assume that rooks can jump over other rooks, in other words a rook can go to any cell which shares vertical and to any cell which shares horizontal.

Ivan wants his arrangement of rooks to have following properties:

  • For any color there is a rook of this color on a board;
  • For any color the set of rooks of this color is connected;
  • For any two different colors $a b$ union of set of rooks of color $a$ and set of rooks of color $b$ is connected if and only if this two colors harmonize with each other.

Please help Ivan find such an arrangement.

è¾“å…¥

The first line of input contains 22 integers $n, m (1â‰¤nâ‰¤100, 0â‰¤mâ‰¤min(1000,n(nâˆ’1)/2)$ â€” number of colors and number of pairs of colors which harmonize with each other.

In next $m$ lines pairs of colors which harmonize with each other are listed. Colors are numbered from $1$ to $n$. It is guaranteed that no pair occurs twice in this list.

è¾“å‡º

Print $n$ blocks, $i-th$ of them describes rooks of $i-th$ color.

In the first line of block print one number $ai (1â‰¤a_iâ‰¤5000)$ â€” number of rooks of color $i$. In each of next $ai$ lines print two integers $x$ and $y$ $(1â‰¤x,yâ‰¤10^9)$ â€” coordinates of the next rook.

All rooks must be on different cells.

Total number of rooks must not exceed $5000$.

It is guaranteed that the solution exists.

If there are many correct answers you can print any. You should not maximize or minimize the number of rooks.

entry.title: ã€Œ2016 ACM/ICPC Asia Regional Dalian Onlineã€F.Football Games
entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

A mysterious country will hold a football world championshipsâ€”-Abnormal Cup, attracting football teams and fans from all around the world. This country is so mysterious that none of the information of the games will be open to the public till the end of all the matches. And finally only the score of each team will be announced.

At the first phase of the championships, teams are divided into M groups using the single round robin rule where one and only one game will be played between each pair of teams within each group. The winner of a game scores 2 points, the loser scores 0, when the game is tied both score 1 point. The schedule of these games are unknown, only the scores of each team in each group are available.

When those games finished, some insider revealed that there were some false scores in some groups. This has aroused great concern among the pubic, so the the Association of Credit Management (ACM) asks you to judge which groupsâ€™ scores must be false.

è¾“å…¥

Multiple test cases, process till end of the input.

For each case, the first line contains a positive integers M, which is the number of groups.
The i-th of the next M lines begins with a positive integer Bi representing the number of teams in the i-th group, followed by Bi nonnegative integers representing the score of each team in this group.

number of test cases <= 10

M<= 100

B[i]<= 20000

score of each team <= 20000

è¾“å‡º

For each test case, output M lines. Output â€œFâ€ (without quotes) if the scores in the i-th group must be false, output â€œTâ€ (without quotes) otherwise. See samples for detail.

entry.title: ã€ŒThe 2016 ACM-ICPC Asia Dalian Regional Contestã€C.Game of Taking Stones(åšå¼ˆè®º+å¤§æ•°)
entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

Two people face two piles of stones and make a game. They take turns to take stones. As game rules, there are two different methods of taking stones: One scheme is that you can take any number of stones in any one pile while the alternative is to take the same amount of stones at the same time in two piles. In the end, the first person taking all the stones is winner.Now,giving the initial number of two stones, can you win this game if you are the first to take stones and both sides have taken the best strategy?

è¾“å…¥

Input contains multiple sets of test data.Each test data occupies one line,containing two non-negative integers a andb,representing the number of two stones.a and b are not more than 10^100.

è¾“å‡º

For each test data,output answer on one line.1 means you are the winner,otherwise output 0.

æ ·ä¾‹

è¾“å…¥

2 1
8 4
4 7

è¾“å‡º

0
1
0

entry.title: ã€ŒThe 13th Zhejiang Provincialã€ D. The Lucky Week
entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

Edward, the headmaster of the Marjar University, is very busy every day and always forgets the date.

There was one day Edward suddenly found that if Monday was the 1st, 11th or 21st day of that month, he could remember the date clearly in that week. Therefore, he called such week â€œThe Lucky Weekâ€.

But now Edward only remembers the date of his first Lucky Week because of the age-related memory loss, and he wants to know the date of the N-th Lucky Week. Can you help him?

entry.content:
æè¿°

ä¼ é€é—¨ï¼šæˆ‘æ˜¯ä¼ é€é—¨

Japari Park is a large zoo home to extant species, endangered species, extinct species, cryptids and some legendary creatures. Due to a mysterious substance known as Sandstar, all the animals have become anthropomorphized into girls known as Friends.

Kaban is a young girl who finds herself in Japari Park with no memory of who she was or where she came from. Shy yet resourceful, she travels through Japari Park along with Serval to find out her identity while encountering more Friends along the way, and eventually discovers that she is a human.

However, Kaban soon finds that itâ€™s also important to identify other Friends. Her friend, Serval, enlightens Kaban that she can use some questions whose expected answers are either â€œyesâ€ or â€œnoâ€ to identitfy a kind of Friends.

To be more specific, there are n Friends need to be identified. Kaban will ask each of them q same questions and collect their answers. For each question, she also gets a full list of animalsâ€™ names that will give a â€œyesâ€ answer to that question (and those animals who are not in the list will give a â€œnoâ€ answer to that question), so itâ€™s possible to determine the name of a Friends by combining the answers and the lists together.

But the work is too heavy for Kaban. Can you help her to finish it?

è¾“å…¥

There are multiple test cases. The first line of the input is an integer T (1 â‰¤ T â‰¤ 100), indicating the number of test cases. Then T test cases follow.

The first line of each test case contains two integers n (1 â‰¤ n â‰¤ 100) and q (1 â‰¤ q â‰¤ 21), indicating the number of Friends need to be identified and the number of questions.

The next line contains an integer c (1 â‰¤ c â‰¤ 200) followed by c strings p1, p2, â€¦ , pc (1 â‰¤ |pi| â‰¤ 20), indicating all known names of Friends.

For the next q lines, the i-th line contains an integer mi (0 â‰¤ mi â‰¤ c) followed by mi strings si, 1, si, 2, â€¦ , si, mi (1 â‰¤ |si, j| â‰¤ 20), indicating the number of Friends and their names, who will give a â€œyesâ€ answer to the i-th question. Itâ€™s guaranteed that all the names appear in the known names of Friends.

For the following n lines, the i-th line contains q integers ai, 1, ai, 2, â€¦ , ai, q (0 â‰¤ ai, j â‰¤ 1), indicating the answer (0 means â€œnoâ€, and 1 means â€œyesâ€) to the j-th question given by the i-th Friends need to be identified.

Itâ€™s guaranteed that all the names in the input consist of only uppercase and lowercase English letters.

è¾“å‡º

For each test case output n lines. If Kaban can determine the name of the i-th Friends need to be identified, print the name on the i-th line. Otherwise, print â€œLetâ€™s go to the library!!â€ (without quotes) on the i-th line instead.

Note

The explanation for the first sample test case is given as follows:

As Serval is the only known animal who gives a â€œyesâ€ answer to the 1st, 2nd and 4th question, and gives a â€œnoâ€ answer to the 3rd question, we output â€œServalâ€ (without quotes) on the first line.

As no animal is known to give a â€œnoâ€ answer to all the questions, we output â€œLetâ€™s go to the library!!â€ (without quotes) on the second line.

Both Alpaca and Moose give a â€œyesâ€ answer to the 1st question, and a â€œnoâ€ answer to the 2nd, 3rd and 4th question. So we canâ€™t determine the name of the third Friends need to be identified, and output â€œLetâ€™s go to the library!!â€ (without quotes) on the third line.

Student Andrey has been skipping physical education lessons for the whole term, and now he must somehow get a passing grade on this subject. Obviously, it is impossible to do this by legal means, but Andrey doesnâ€™t give up. Having obtained an empty certificate from a local hospital, he is going to use his knowledge of local doctorâ€™s handwriting to make a counterfeit certificate of illness. A clique is a complete graph, in which there is an edge between every pair of the vertices. Given a graph with N vertices and M edges, your task is to count the number of cliques with a specific size S in the graph.

è¾“å…¥

The first line is the number of test cases. For each test case, the first line contains 3 integers N,M and S (N â‰¤ 100,M â‰¤ 1000,2 â‰¤ S â‰¤ 10), each of the following M lines contains 2 integers u and v (1 â‰¤ u < v â‰¤ N), which means there is an edge between vertices u and v. It is guaranteed that the maximum degree of the vertices is no larger than 20.

è¾“å‡º

For each test case, output the number of cliques with size S in the graph.
